as discussed in sig-auth, we need to make sure the requirement of these flags would not make the adoption of 1.20 painful. reaching out to owners of clouds and deployment automation to confirm this change:

clouds:
- [x] Google
- [x] AWS (confirmed with @micahhausler )
- [x] Azure (confirmed with @ritazh )
- [x] VMware (confirmed with @dims )
- [x] Red Hat (confirmed with @deads2k )
- [x] IBM (confirmed with @rtheis )
- [ ] ...

deployment automation:
- [x] kubeadm (confirmed with @neolit123 )
- [ ] ...

@liggitt, i discussed this on slack with @zshihang .

i'm making a couple of assumptions, but please correct me if i'm missing something:
- kubeadm X deploying apiserver X-1 (skew) would be fine with the new flags since they existed since 1.12 and the feature was already Beta.
- during immutable note upgrades, kubeadm creating a control-plane node with apiserver version X that has the new flags would not cause a problem with an existing apiserver version X-1 that was deployed without the flags. this should be a temporary condition and eventually all apiserver instances would be at version X with the flags, once the upgrade finishes.

/approve 
for kubeadm

> as discussed in sig-auth, we need to make sure the requirement of these flags would not make the adoption of 1.20 painful. reaching out to owners of clouds and deployment automation to confirm this change:

Thanks for the heads up. This change is ok for our (RH) deployments.

One rough edge we did find that may burn people on upgrade though.  If issuers or audiences change, old tokens become invalid (this is good), but the kube-controller-manager's logic does not attempt to get new tokens for about 45 minutes or so.  If people have a two stage upgrade (we tried this first), then their kube-controller-manager can appear wedged during the upgrade.

> the kube-controller-manager's logic does not attempt to get new tokens for about 45 minutes or so

we're wrapping the transport already... expiring the cached token on a 401 response from the server seems like it would be reasonable

> Does kubeadm do any kind of rotation of the service account token signing keys as part of upgrade or cert rotation?

no, currently it does not. it signs a SA key for 10 years, similarly to the CA key (if managed by kubeadm).

> The ideal rollout for kubeadm would be:
> In release N, set TokenRequest flags, so all API servers recognize tokens issued by the TokenRequest API
> In release N+1, enable BoundServiceAccountTokenVolumes, so pods get bound tokens by default, and API servers still on the
> previous version recognize those tokens

so given we are adding the flags for TokenRequest in 1.20, does this mean that if BoundServiceAccountTokenVolumes goes beta in 1.20, ideally we should keep it disabled (on the kubeadm side) until 1.21?

> it signs a SA key for 10 years, similarly to the CA key (if managed by kubeadm).

fwiw, the raw SA key doesn't actually expire like an x509 cert

> so given we are adding the flags for TokenRequest in 1.20, does this mean that if BoundServiceAccountTokenVolumes goes beta in 1.20, ideally we should keep it disabled (on the kubeadm side) until 1.21?

Enabling BoundServiceAccountTokenVolumes in 1.20 would be fine for:
1. new clusters
2. single-server upgrades
3. multi-server upgrades where the previous servers had already enabled TokenRequest flags

I don't know how much context kubeadm has about existing servers/config when upgrading.

> fwiw, the raw SA key doesn't actually expire like an x509 cert

that is true, i got somewhat confused.

i think kubeadm's cert rotation refreshing the SA public and private keys would be disruptive to existing setups, unless users manually rotate the SA in their workloads as well.
with BoundServiceAccountTokenVolumes should we start rotating the SA public and private keys as well during the "kubeadm cert rotation" process, wouldn't that still require the users to rotate unless they want to wait for the automatic rotation period (~48mins)?

EDIT: thinking about this more, it opens some complications.

> I don't know how much context kubeadm has about existing servers/config when upgrading.

for immutable node upgrades it does not have context about the existing apiserver instances and cannot patch them.
it only knows about the nodes it runs on and a few cluster resources (CM, RBAC, etc..).

for this scenario:
- 1.19 apiserver doesn't have the flags (as per the kubeadm defaults)
- 1.20 apiserver joins the cluster and has the flags (as per the new kubeadm defaults from this PR)

i guess this means if we "true" BoundServiceAccountTokenVolumes in 1.20 there is an "action required" for the higher level "tool" up the stack that does the immutable upgrade using kubeadm nodes, to patch the configuration of 1.19 instances.

would it be better if we "true" BoundServiceAccountTokenVolumes in 1.21 on the side of kubeadm?

> i think kubeadm's cert rotation refreshing the SA public and private keys would be disruptive to existing setups, unless users manually rotate the SA in their workloads as well.
> with BoundServiceAccountTokenVolumes should we start rotating the SA public and private keys as well during the "kubeadm cert rotation" process, wouldn't that still require the users to rotate unless they want to wait for the automatic rotation period (~48mins)?
> 
> EDIT: thinking about this more, it opens some complications.

If kubeadm doesn't rotate now, then I wouldn't couple rotation to this change. It's worth thinking about separately though.

> would it be better if we "true" BoundServiceAccountTokenVolumes in 1.21 on the side of kubeadm?

Unless the kubeadm user explicitly asked for BoundServiceAccountTokenVolumes=true, maybe? I'm a bit fuzzy on how the version of kubeadm maps to the version of k8s... if you used a 1.21 kubeadm to deploy a 1.20 cluster and then upgrade it, what would you envision happening?

> If kubeadm doesn't rotate now, then I wouldn't couple rotation to this change. It's worth thinking about separately though.

ok, agreed.

>> would it be better if we "true" BoundServiceAccountTokenVolumes in 1.21 on the side of kubeadm?

> Unless the kubeadm user explicitly asked for BoundServiceAccountTokenVolumes=true, maybe? I'm a bit fuzzy on how the version of kubeadm maps to the version of k8s... if you used a 1.21 kubeadm to deploy a 1.20 cluster and then upgrade it, what would you envision happening?

kubeadm 1.21 would just write the static Pod manifest for a 1.20 kube-apiserver on CP nodes, with the appropriate config for 1.20, presumably. then for upgrades:
- if kubeadm in-place upgrades a node (via "kubeadm upgrade"), it would just write a new static Pod manifest for kube-apiserver 1.21 using the 1.21 variant of the config also stored in the kubeadm binary for 1.21. it may not differ from the 1.20 variant. notably, this operation is done one CP node at a time, so there is a period when there will be 1.20 / 1.21 kube-apiservers.
- for re-place upgrades "kubeadm join" can join a 1.21 instance of the kube-apiserver to the cluster that already has 1.20 kube-servers. the old CP nodes are removed and the new nodes that host kube-apiserver 1.21 would replace them. again for a period of time there will be 1.20 / 1.21 kube-apiservers.

> The ideal rollout for kubeadm would be:
> - In release N, set TokenRequest flags, so all API servers recognize tokens issued by the TokenRequest API
> - In release N+1, enable BoundServiceAccountTokenVolumes, so pods get bound tokens by default, and API servers still on the previous version recognize those tokens

>> so given we are adding the flags for TokenRequest in 1.20, does this mean that if BoundServiceAccountTokenVolumes goes beta in 1.20, ideally we should keep it disabled (on the kubeadm side) until 1.21?

> Enabling BoundServiceAccountTokenVolumes in 1.20 would be fine for:
> - new clusters
> - single-server upgrades
> - multi-server upgrades where the previous servers had already enabled TokenRequest flags

my understanding is that for multi-server upgrades it is not fine to have BoundServiceAccountTokenVolumes enabled in 1.20 (at least on the side of kubeadm), because as per the above "kubeadm upgrade" summary there will be 1.19 kube-apiserver instances that were configured without the TokenRequest flags, and kubeadm cannot mutate those 1.19 instances to enable them.
/retest
/retest
/retest
/retest
i'd like to get this PR in 1.20 so that 1.20 apiserver by default can recognize bound tokens issued by 1.21 apiserver in a multi-server upgrade.
/remove-area kubeadm

/lgtm
